results.headline: Review: Soul of Calypso Elevates the Bollywood-Flavored ‘Bazodee’
results.summary_short: This romance finds an Indian family from London visiting another in Trinidad and Tobago for a party celebrating their children’s engagement.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bazodee

results.headline: Review: In ‘Front Cover,’ Struggling for Self-Acceptance
results.summary_short: This gay romance, written and directed by Ray Yeung, takes a gentle, thoughtful look at the intersection of ethnicity and sexuality.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Front Cover

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Brooklyn Banker,’ Troy Garity Shows Promise (With the Mob)
results.summary_short: The latest entry in the gangster genre, this drama concerns a number cruncher who proves more useful for local gangsters than is healthy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Brooklyn Banker

results.headline: Review: War Made Terrifyingly Palpable in ‘Citizen Soldier’
results.summary_short: This documentary powerfully uses footage to track a group of American soldiers during a tour of duty in Afghanistan in 2011.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Citizen Soldier

results.headline: Review: ‘collective:unconscious,’ the Stuff of Dreams Reinterpreted
results.summary_short: In this omnibus work about the individuality of interpretation, five filmmakers transcribed their dreams, which were then directed by others in the group as shorts.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of collective:unconscious

results.headline: Review: ‘Five Nights in Maine’ Probes the Pain of Loss
results.summary_short: In Maris Curran’s delicate drama, a man whose wife has died goes to visit her mother, and the two slowly examine their grief.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Five Nights in Maine

results.headline: Review: The Lobster Scene in ‘Multiple Maniacs’? It Still Startles
results.summary_short: A restoration by the Criterion Collection puts this early John Waters film back on the screen — and in theaters — in all its perverted glory.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Multiple Maniacs

results.headline: Review: ‘Richard Linklater: Dream Is Destiny’ Lionizes a Maverick Talent
results.summary_short: Louis Black’s film is a cozily chronological ramble through a director’s career highlights and personal reminiscences.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Richard Linklater: Dream Is Destiny

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Tenth Man,’ Contending With a Father and a Traditional Upbringing
results.summary_short: A charmer with a documentary feel, this film follows a man’s return to Buenos Aires to reconnect with his father in a bustling Jewish neighborhood.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Tenth Man

results.headline: Review: ‘Olympic Pride, American Prejudice’ Recalls Black Athletes in 1936
results.summary_short: This documentary, directed by Deborah Riley Draper, brings racial inequality to the forefront in the Olympics held in Berlin during the Third Reich.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Olympic Pride, American Prejudice

results.headline: Review: ‘Suicide Squad’ Chases Nihilistic Swagger but Trips Over Its Own Feet
results.summary_short: The death toll is high, and the weapons are nasty, but the overall mood is cautious in this superhero movie from David Ayer.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Suicide Squad

results.headline: Review: In ‘Gleason,’ a Devastating Diagnosis Prompts a New Mission
results.summary_short: Clay Tweel’s documentary chronicles the athlete Steve Gleason’s attempt to leave behind a meaningful legacy for his unborn child as A.L.S. wreaks havoc on his body.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gleason

results.headline: Review: ‘Indignation’ Offers a Precisely Rendered, and Repressive, 1950s America
results.summary_short: A period novel by Philip Roth, inspired by his own college years, is the basis of this tale about a young Jewish man and sex and morality in the Korean War era.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Indignation

results.headline: Review: In ‘Equity,’ No Room for Sisterhood Amid Gloves-Off Wall Street Warfare
results.summary_short: Meera Menon’s film, starring Anna Gunn, challenges stereotypes of ambition, corruption and sexism, even as it exploits their tenacity.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Equity

results.headline: Review: Empty Spaces Show the Imprint of Humanity in ‘Homo Sapiens’
results.summary_short: Images of abandoned places built or scarred by humankind make up what could be described as an environmental documentary.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Homo Sapiens

results.headline: Review: Three Women (and a Baby) at a Crossroads in ‘Tallulah’
results.summary_short: Almost a decade after “Juno,” Ellen Page and Allison Janney are paired again in this film written and directed by Sian Heder.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tallulah

results.headline: Review: ‘Into the Forest’: Be Very, Very Quiet. The World’s Ending.
results.summary_short: This apocalyptic film by the Canadian filmmaker Patricia Rozema depends on atmosphere and details, rather than big incidents, to tell its story.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Into the Forest

results.headline: Review: ‘On the Silver Globe,’ Andrzej Zulawski’s Thwarted Sci-Fi Masterwork
results.summary_short: To say that this sprawling, unfinished film by a renegade Polish director is unlike anything else being released this summer is a drastic understatement.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of On the Silver Globe

results.headline: Review: ‘Ants on a Shrimp’ and Other Delicacies Test a Chef’s Mettle
results.summary_short: Maurice Dekkers’s film follows the renowned chef René Redzepi and his team to Tokyo, where they invent a menu of original dishes limited to Japanese ingredients.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ants on a Shrimp

results.headline: Review: ‘Can We Take a Joke?’ The Answer Appears to Be Not Anymore
results.summary_short: In this one-sided documentary, comedians like Gilbert Gottfried and Lisa Lampanelli argue that people need to develop thicker skin.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Can We Take a Joke?
